[[Image:Squantoteaching.png|thumb|1911 illustration of Tisquantum, or Squanto, teaching the [[Plymouth Colony|Plymouth colonists]] to plant [[maize]].]]
[[Image:Squantoteaching.png|thumb|1911 illustration of Tisquantum, or Squanto, teaching the [[Plymouth Colony|Plymouth colonists]] to plant [[maize]].]]
'''Tisquantum''' (better known as '''Squanto''') (c. 1580s â November 1622) was a Patuxet. He was the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] who assisted the [[Pilgrim (Plymouth Colony)|Pilgrims]] after their first winter in the New World and was integral to their survival. The [[Patuxet tribe]] was a [[Tributary state|tributary]] of the [[Wampanoag people|Wampanoag Confederacy]].
'''Tisquantum''' (better known as '''Squanto''') (c. 1580s â November 1622) was a Patuxet. He was the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] who assisted the [[Pilgrim (Plymouth Colony)|Pilgrims]] after their first winter in the New World and was integral to their survival. The [[Patuxet tribe]] was a [[Tributary state|tributary]] of the [[Wampanoag people|Wampanoag Confederacy]].

==Caedens Bio==
+
==Biography==
On his way back to the Patuxet in 1614, Tisquantum was kidnapped by Englishman Thomas Hunt. Hunt was one of [[John Smith (explorer)|John Smith]]'s lieutenants. Hunt was planning to sell fish, corn, and captured natives in [[MÃ¡laga]], [[Spain]]. There Hunt attempted to sell Tisquantum and a number of other [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] into slavery in Spain for Â£20 apiece.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mosmd/squanto.htm |title= Squanto | publisher= Roots Web | accessdate= 30 Nov 2009}}</ref>
